title: FRQ Titration of HF with NaOH

content.question: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="H F"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the titration of <math alttext="H F aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) In the following box, draw the complete Lewis electron-dot diagram of the <math alttext="H F"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule.

frqParts.text: For parts of the free-response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate. Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="H F"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and the titration of <math alttext="H F aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. (a) In the following box, draw the complete Lewis electron-dot diagram of the <math alttext="H F"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecule.

<math alttext="H F aqueous plus O H with a negative one charge, aqueous, react to produce, F with a negative one charge aqueous plus H 2 O liquid"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>F</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>A student performed a titration of <math alttext="H F aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="N a O H aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The net ionic equation for the neutralization reaction that occurs during the titration is shown above.(b) Identify both of the Brønsted-Lowry conjugate acid-base pairs in the neutralization reaction above. For each pair, label the acid and the base.
(c) In terms of the species in the reaction, explain what occurs during the reaction that identifies it as an acid-base reaction.
(d) The equation can be written in particulate form. Using the following key, draw the correct products above their formulas.

A student titrated <math alttext="30 decimal point milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.15 molar H F aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.15</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="0.30 molar N a O H aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. The results are plotted on the following graph. (e) How many moles of HF are in <math alttext="30 decimal point milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.15 molar H F aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.15</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>?

(f) Draw an <math alttext="X"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>X</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> on the horizontal axis of the graph to show the amount of <math alttext="N a O H aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> that had been added when the equivalence point was reached.

(g) The graph above shows the results of the titration of the <math alttext="30 decimal point milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.15 molar H F aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.15</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="0.30 molar N a O H aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>. On the same graph, draw the curve for the titration of <math alttext="60 decimal point milliliters"><mstyle><mrow><mn>60.</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.15 molar H F aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.15</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HF</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> with <math alttext="0.30 molar N a O H aqueous"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.30</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

skill.text: 1.B: Describe the components of and quantitative information from models and representations that illustrate both particulate-level and macroscopic- level properties.
